chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected vitiligo?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If a person has a suspected diagnosis of vitiligo, determine whether it is non-segmental or segmental following clinical examination.

  • Ask about:
    • The extent and duration of lesions, lesion activity and spread, and rate of progression or regression of lesions.
    • The impact on the person's quality of life, psychosocial issues, or other complications. See the CKS topics on Generalized anxiety disorder and Depression for more information.
    • The person's skin type (skin colour and ability to tan), which may affect treatment options. See the section on Skin type classification for more information.
    • Any known triggers including occupational history/exposure to chemicals.
    • Any known risk factors, such as family history, or personal or family history of autoimmune disease, which may accompany non-segmental vitiligo.
    • Any previous episodes of spontaneous repigmentation, previous treatments and their effectiveness.
  • Examine the person for:
    • The distribution and extent of lesions and any mucosal involvement.
    • The presence of Koebner's phenomenon, confetti-like depigmentation, poorly defined or inflamed borders of lesions, trichome vitiligo, or depigmented hairs, which may suggest more active disease.
    • Skin type (skin colour and ability to tan).
    • The estimated percentage of body surface area affected in adults using Wallace's 'Rule of Nines' (may overestimate the area affected):
      • Posterior trunk — 18%.
      • Anterior trunk — 18%.
      • Leg — 18%.
      • Neck — 1%.
      • Head — 9%.
      • Arm — 9%.
    • Alternatively, the estimated percentage of body surface area affected using a Lund and Browder chart (this is more accurate, and can be used in adults and children).
  • Consider arranging blood tests for co-morbid autoimmune disease if a diagnosis of non-segmental vitiligo is suspected, such as:
    • Thyroid function tests and thyroid autoantibodies. See the CKS topic on Hypothyroidism for more information.
    • Note: checking autoantibodies for other autoimmune conditions is only recommended if the person's history, family history, and/or other test results are suggestive.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Skin type classification
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The information in Table 1 provides a classification of skin type according to skin colour and ability to tan.

Table 1. Fitzpatrick skin type

Skin typeTypical featuresTanning ability
IPale white skin, blue/hazel eyes, blonde/red hairAlways burns, does not tan
IIFair skin, blue eyesBurns easily, tans poorly
IIIDarker white skinTans after initial burn
IVLighter brown skinBurns minimally, tans easily
VBrown skinRarely burns, tans darkly easily
VIDark brown or black skinNever burns, always tans darkly
Data from [Fitzpatrick, 1988]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on assessment are largely based on the British Association of Dermatologists (BAD) publication Guideline for the diagnosis and management of vitiligo [Gawkrodger, 2008]; the Vitiligo European Task Force (VETF) consensus documents The definition and assessment of vitiligo [Taieb, 2007] and Revised classification/nomenclature of vitiligo and related issues: the Vitiligo Global Issues Consensus Conference [Ezzedine, 2012]; the European Dermatology Forum consensus document Guidelines for the management of vitiligo [Taieb, 2013]; a cross-sectional study on autoimmune disease in people with vitiligo [Gill, 2016]; a systematic review of the prevalence of psychological co-morbidity in people with vitiligo [Osinubi, 2017]; a systematic review of quality of life in people with vitiligo [Morrison, 2017]; a meta-analysis of clinical signs of active disease in vitiligo [van Geel, 2019]; and expert opinion in review articles on vitiligo [Ezzedine, 2015; Goh, 2017; Bergqvist, 2020], on vitiligo in children [Ezzedine, 2016], on hypopigmentation disorders [Hill, 2017], and in a chapter in a medical textbook [Gupta and Ramam, 2014].

Clinical features on history taking

  • The recommendation to differentiate between segmental and non-segmental vitiligo is important because these subtypes differ in terms of prognosis, natural history, and response to treatment [Ezzedine, 2012; Ezzedine, 2016].
  • The recommendations on the clinical features in the history to assess for people with suspected vitiligo are based on the VETF consensus document [Taieb, 2007], the European Dermatology Forum consensus document [Taieb, 2013], and expert opinion in review articles [Ezzedine, 2016; Bergqvist, 2020].
  • The importance of assessing psychosocial issues and impact on quality of life is highlighted in the BAD guideline publication [Gawkrodger, 2008], the European Dermatology Forum consensus document [Taieb, 2013], and expert opinion in review articles [Ezzedine, 2016; Hill, 2017; Bergqvist, 2020].
  • The recommendation to assess for risk factors including occupational history/exposure to chemicals is based on the European Dermatology Forum consensus document [Taieb, 2013] and is also extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article, as a positive occupational history may suggest a differential diagnosis [Bergqvist, 2020].
  • The recommendation to assess for a history of co-existing autoimmune disorders is based on the BAD guideline publication [Gawkrodger, 2008], the European Dermatology Forum consensus document [Taieb, 2013], and expert opinion in review articles [Ezzedine, 2015; Ezzedine, 2016; Bergqvist, 2020].

Clinical features on examination

  • The BAD guideline publication notes that a full skin examination is important to assess disease severity and individual prognostic factors [Gawkrodger, 2008]. This approach is supported by expert opinion in a review article [Bergqvist, 2020].
  • The information on the clinical features that may suggest more active disease is based on a meta-analysis of clinical signs of active disease in vitiligo [van Geel, 2019], the European Dermatology Forum consensus document [Taieb, 2013], and expert opinion in review articles [Goh, 2017; Bergqvist, 2020].
    • Signs of active disease may indicate prognosis and can affect specialist treatment choices [Goh, 2017].
    • The presence of Koebner’s phenomenon represents a clinical marker of active, progressive disease, and measures to avoid mechanical trauma in such people may help in the prevention of vitiligo [Taieb, 2013; Bergqvist, 2020].
  • The recommendation to assess the person's skin type is based on the BAD guideline publication [Gawkrodger, 2008].
  • The recommendation to assess the extent of disease using the 'Rule of Nines' is based on the VETF consensus document [Taieb, 2007] and expert opinion in a medical textbook [Gupta and Ramam, 2014]. The recommendation to consider alternative use of a Lund and Browder chart is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be sensible clinical practice.

Arranging blood tests for co-existing autoimmune disease

  • The information on when to consider arranging blood tests for co-existing autoimmune disease is based on the fact there is an increased prevalence of autoimmune thyroid and other disease in people with non-segmental vitiligo compared with the general population [Gawkrodger, 2008; Taieb, 2013; Ezzedine, 2015; Ezzedine, 2016; Bergqvist, 2020].
    • A US cross-sectional cohort study on autoimmune disease in people with vitiligo (n = 1098) found nearly 20% of people had at least one co-morbid autoimmune disease, and rates were higher than in the general population. The authors noted, however, there was no control group included in the study, and there was potential selection bias as the study was conducted in a single institution setting [Gill, 2016].
